member.name: M:Endeca.Web.UI.Design.EndecaDataSourceDesigner.CreateSchema(System.Object)
member.remarks:
We want to create a data table that represents the schema of the specified object. This has to be done in one of several ways, depending on the type of the specified object. - If the object is not enumerable, the schema basically represents the public properties of the object. - If the object is enumerable, and is not empty, then the schema is generated by the set of properties exposed by each item in the missingDefaultParams. It is possible that each item in the missingDefaultParams may have a different set of properties (due to custom type descriptors and our interface, so we need to go through each item in the collection. - If the object is enumerable but empty, we attempt to determine the type of objects that the missingDefaultParams could contain by inspecting the type of the missingDefaultParams. If we can determine the type of the objects in the collection, then the schema represents the public properties of the type.
In addition to creating a table that represents the schema of the object, we populate the table with some rows. If this designer has the PreviewLiveData flag set, then we attempt to read data directly from the result object. Otherwise we just generate some fake data.

member.name: T:Endeca.Web.UI.Design.UserProfileCollectionEditor
member.summary: A collection that forces the collection editor design-time dialog to create instances, instead of instances. The reason we do this is that the Visual Studio designer gets confused when a user uses the designer dialogs to edit the UserProfiles property of a NavigationDataSource, and there is no {%@ Register %} tag on the web form for the Endeca.Data namespace, then the designer generates invalid markup, and does not correctly add the register tag. By forcing the editor to create a UserProfile instance that is in the same namespace/assembly as the NavigationDataSource itself, we are able to sidestep this issue.

member.name: T:Endeca.Web.UI.Design.RefinementConfigCollectionEditor
member.summary: A collection that forces the collection editor design-time dialog to create instances, instead of instances. The reason we do this is that the Visual Studio designer gets confused in a user uses the designer dialogs to edit the RefinementConfigs or PermenantRefinementConfigs collections of a NavigationDataSource, and there is no {%@ Register %} tag on the web form for the Endeca.Data namespace, then the designer generates invalid markup, and does not correctly add the register tag. By forcing the editor to create a RefinementConfig instance that is in the same namespace/assembly as the NavigationDataSource itself, we are able to sidestep this issue.

member.summary: Initializes the state of commands or data sources represented by the parameter from query parameters in parameter. Query parameters are associated with Endeca commands by ID (the query parameter name must be the same as the command ID). If a parameter name matching a command ID is found, the value of that parameter is deserialized by a to initialize the command or data source. This is done using RAW (not UrlDecoded) query parameters. Any remaining query parameters are UrlDecoded and added to the collection.
member.param: A URL, generated by a previous call to .
List of objects describing the s that should be initialized from the state encoded in .
A collection of additional parameters that should be initialized from the state encoded in .

member.name: T:Endeca.Web.Url.UrlBuilder
member.summary: Provides methods to construct URLs that represent the state of the s and that have been registered with a .
member.remarks:
When building URLs, the state that is included in the URL is in general the state of the commands and parameters that are associated with a . However it is typically the case that the exact state that should be in the URL represents a modification to the 'base' state represented by the .
therefore provides methods to construct URLs by allowing an application to obtain a copy of the commands (or parameters) registered with the manager, and then modify these copies to reflect the desired state that should be represented in the URL. The method provides this basic functionality.
In addition to this method, has a selection of higher-level helper functions, such as , representing modifications that are commonly used when building Endeca applications.

member.name: M:Endeca.Web.Url.UrlBuilder.BuildUrl(System.Action{Endeca.Web.Url.CommandActionInfo})
member.summary: Builds a URL that represents the state of the commands and parameters associated with a .
member.remarks:
The BuildUrl method constructs a URL by encoding the state of one or more objects into a URL. The commands that are included in this encoding process are in general the commands that have been registered with the associated with this builder. However, the exact state that is encoded typically reflects a modification (delta) from the base state of these commands.
The desired modification(s) to the command or commands is specified by the delegate. The implementation of this delegate can request copies of the commands that have been registered with the by calling , and then alter the state of these copies to reflect the desired state that should be encoded into the URL. If any commands were registered with the but not copied by calling in the action delegate, then the state of those unmodified commands is also encoded into the URL.
In addition to the state of one or more commands, the URL can include arbitrary name-value pairs. These name-value pairs are represented by the collection. Similar to the manner in which the delegate can obtain copies of the commands registered with the , the delegate can obtain a copy of the collection. The delegate can then alter this copy to specify the exact name-value parameters to include in the URL.
Note that the algorithm by which commands and parameters are encoded into a URL is represented by the associated with the . The method of this provider is called after the action delegate is invoked to produce the URL that is returned by this method.
member.param: A delegate that represents the changes to make to the commands and parameters registered with a , in order to transition to the desired state that should be encoded in the URL.
member.exception: if is null.

member.name: T:Endeca.Web.Url.UrlManager
member.summary: Provides functionality to construct URLs based on the state of one or more commands or data sources, and to initialize commands and datasources from state encoded in a URL.
member.remarks:
provides the following capabilities:
Registering commands and data sources with a manager so that that the URLs that are generated represent the combined state of these objects.
Generating URLs representing the state of the commands and datasources registered with the manager.
Initializing the state of registered commands data sources from by deconstructing a URL.
An application can obtain an instance of a by calling . Once the instance is obtained, commands and data sources can be registered by calling . Note that is able to handle data sources and commands in a uniform fashion through the use of the interface. All the standard Endeca commands and data sources implement this interface.
Once commands and data sources have been registered with a manager, URLs can be generated by calling methods on the object available from the property. Refer to the documentation for for further details.
Note that the specific algorithm used for encoding and decoding the state of s to and from URLs is represented by an instance of the class. Each is associated with a by the property. This property will return a instance by default; applications may customize this by assigning a different implementation if necessary.
In addition to generating URLs, the commands and data source registered with a can be initialized from a URL (previously generated by a ). The method acccepts a URL, and updates the state of the commands and data sources registered with the manager to reflect the state encoded in the URL. The algorithm for decoding the state is represented by the associated with the manager.

member.summary: Gets the with the specified ID, creating it if necessary.
member.remarks:
This method offers a convenient way to create and share a instance among the controls on an ASP.NET page. The first time during a page request that this method is called, and new instance is created and stored in the collection of the current . Subsequent calls with the same will return this instance.
Because the same instance is returned, controls anywhere in the control hierarchy can access the manager by name, relieving page developers from the task of sharing a global instance.

member.name: M:Endeca.Web.Url.UrlManager.GetDefaultCommand(Endeca.Data.Provider.ICommandSource)
member.summary:
Returns a copy of the specified command. Note that the copy may have already been performed if the command source was already registered with a UrlManager. If so, the copy that was previously made is returned.
The motivation for this logic is to handle gracefully something like the following code:
NavigationDataSource dsNav = ... UrlManager.Get("1").Register( dsNav ); UrlManager.Get("1").InitializeFrom( Request.Url ); UrlManager.Get("2").Register( dsNav ); string url = UrlManager.Get("2").Urls.BuildUrl();
In this code, a data source is registered with two data sources, but InitializeFrom is called before registering with the second manager. Each time the data source is registered, we need to determine an appropriate 'default' version of the command. It is problematic to simply copy the command that was passed to Register, because if InitializeFrom was already called, then the data source is likely not in a state that the user intends as the default. It is possible that the URL that was built may not include any state from the command at all, because it is considered to be in its 'default' state. However if we use the the default command that was established when the command was registered with the first manager, then we avoid the wrong state being used as the default.

member.name: T:Endeca.Web.UI.NavigationDataSource
member.summary: A data source that performs a navigation query against an MDEX Engine.
member.remarks:
This data source supports many views. The primary view has the name and returns a instance providing full access to the results of the navigation query.
All of the other views provide 'shortcuts' to commonly-used objects and collections made available by . There is one view for each public property (with the same name as the property) of . These views return the value of the corresponding property. Additionally, there is one view for each property of these sub-objects that returns an instance. These additional views have names with the format [NavigationResult property name].[IEnumerable property name].
For example, defines a property; therefore, there is a view named 'RecordsResult' that returns a instance. Because has a property that is , there is also a view named 'RecordsResult.Records' that returns this collection.
